sen.j: 弟橘媛/乙橘媛（おとたちばなひめ）は、日本神話に登場するヤマトタケルの后。
sen.e: Oto Tachibana Hime is the wife of Prince Yamatotakeru who appears in Japanese mythology.
Oto Tachibana Hime was the wife of a mythical Japanese prince called Yamatotakeru.
Oto Tachibana Hime was the wife of a mythical Japanese prince called Yamatotakeru.

sen.j: 弟橘比売命（おとたちばなひめのみこと）、大橘比売命（おおたちばなひめのみこと）、橘皇后（たちばなのおおきさき）『古事記』では弟橘姬とも言う。
sen.e: Ototachibanahime no Mikoto, Otachibanahime no Mikoto, or Tachibanano Okisaki is also called as Oto Tachibana Hime in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).
Also known as Ototachibanahime no Mikoto, Otachibanahime no Mikoto, or Tachibanano Okisaki, she is referred to as Oto Tachibana Hime in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).
sen.cmt: A native speaker of English reading this would have no idea what this list is supposed to mean. Please remind the translator that he/she may need to add some information to the translation in order to ensure that it will make sense in English
sen.e: Also known as Ototachibanahime no Mikoto, Otachibanahime no Mikoto, or Tachibanano Okisaki, she is referred to as Oto Tachibana Hime in the "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: 彼女の事跡は日本書紀の景行天皇紀、および古事記の中巻、常陸国風土記に記されている。
sen.e: The records of Oto Tachibana Hime are found in "Emperor Keiko Period" in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan), the second book of Kojiki, and Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki (the topography of Hitachi Province).
sen.cmt: 『日本書紀』を確認したところ、「景行天皇記」という章建てではなく「巻第七 大足彦忍代別天皇 景行天皇」となっていますが、" Chapter 7, "Emperor Keiko" in "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan)"とはせず原文通りに訳出しました。
sen.e: Mention of her can be found in the section of the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) entitled "Emperor Keiko Period," as well as in the second book of the Kojiki and in Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki (literally, "the topography of Hitachi Province").

Mention of her can be found in the section of the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) entitled "Emperor Keiko Period," as well as in the second book of the Kojiki and in Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki (literally, "the topography of Hitachi Province").

sen.j: 記紀の弟橘媛
sen.e: Oto Tachibana Hime recorded in the Kiki (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki)
Oto Tachibana Hime according to the Kojiki and Nihonshoki
sen.cmt: I don't think the reader needs to know the Japanese word used to refer to the Kojiki and Nihonshiki so I have deleted it.
sen.e: Oto Tachibana Hime according to the Kojiki and Nihonshoki

sen.j: 穂積氏忍山宿禰（ほづみのうじのおしやまのすくね）の娘だという。
sen.e: It is said that she is the daughter of Hozuminoujino Oshiyamano Sukune.
It is said that she was the daughter of Hozuminoujino Oshiyamano Sukune.
It is said that she was the daughter of Hozuminoujino Oshiyamano Sukune.

sen.j: 尊との間に稚武彦王（わかたけひこのみこ）を設ける。
sen.e: She bore Yamatotakeru a son, Wakatakehiko no Miko.
sen.cmt: 稚武彦王の性別がわかるよう"a son"を加えて訳しました。
sen.e: She bore Yamatotakeru a son, Wakatakehiko no Miko.
She bore Yamatotakeru a son, Wakatakehiko no Miko.

sen.j: 尊の東征に同行。
sen.e: She accompanied Yamatotakeru to the eastern expedition.
She accompanied Yamatotakeru to the eastern expedition.
She accompanied Yamatotakeru to the eastern expedition.

sen.j: 走水（はしりみず）の海（現在の浦賀水道）に至った時、尊の軽はずみな言動が海神の怒りを招く。
sen.e: When they arrived at Hashirimizu no umi (present day the Uraga Channel), Yamatotakeru's thoughtless words and deeds aroused the anger of Watatsumi (a tutelary of the sea).
sen.cmt: 「尊の軽はずみな言動」を原文に忠実に訳しましたが、日本書紀では「海を望み、言霊の力を借りて言い立てて、「これは小さな海だ。飛び越えてでも渡ることができよう」」 (『日本書紀 1』、小学館、p. 375) と書かれているため"Yamatotakeru's thoughtless remarks aroused the anger of"としたほうがように思います。
sen.e: When they arrived at Hashirimizu no umi (present day the Uraga Channel), Yamatotakeru's thoughtless words and deeds aroused the anger of Watatsumi (a tutelary of the sea).
When they arrived at Hashirimizu no umi (present day the Uraga Channel), Yamatotakeru's thoughtless words and deeds aroused the anger of Watatsumi (a tutelary of the sea).

sen.j: 海は荒れ狂い、先に進むことが不可能になった。
sen.e: The sea became very rough and they couldn't go any farther.
The sea became very rough and they could not go any farther.
The sea became very rough and they could not go any farther.

sen.j: 海神の怒りを解くため、弟橘媛は「私は夫である皇子の身に替わって海に入水します。どうぞ皇子の東征を護らせ給え」と念じた。
sen.e: In order to soothe the anger of Watatsumi, Oto Tachibana Hime prayed: "I will sacrifice myself for my husband, Prince Yamatotakeru, by drowning myself in the sea. I beg you to protect his expedition to the east."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In order to soothe the anger of Watatsumi, Oto Tachibana Hime prayed: 'I will sacrifice myself for my husband, Prince Yamatotakeru, by drowning myself in the sea. I beg you to protect his expedition to the east.'
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: In order to soothe the anger of Watatsumi, Oto Tachibana Hime prayed: 'I will sacrifice myself for my husband, Prince Yamatotakeru, by drowning myself in the sea. I beg you to protect his expedition to the east.'

sen.j: 浪の上に管畳八枚、皮畳八枚、絹畳八枚を敷いて、その上に座って入水した。
sen.e: She spread eight Sugadatami (sedge mats), eight Kawadatami (skin mats), and eight Kinudatami (silk mats) on the waves and sat on them to drown herself in the sea.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処原文では「管畳」となっていますが、他の著書では「菅畳や皮・絹製の敷物」 (島崎晋著『面白いほどよくわかる古事記』 p. 184) や「菅・皮・絹の畳をそれぞれ 8 畳ずつ」 (多田元監修『もう一度学びたい古事記と日本書紀』 p. 114) となっているため「菅」として訳しました。 原文からは皮畳が具体的に何の皮かの記載がありませんが、『古事記』の火遠理命が登場する話のなかでアシカの皮畳 (皮の敷物) の記述が出てくるため、皮 (skin) としました。
sen.e: She spread eight Sugadatami (sedge mats), eight Kawadatami (skin mats), and eight Kinudatami (silk mats) on the waves and sat on them to drown herself in the sea.
She spread eight Sugadatami (sedge mats), eight Kawadatami (skin mats), and eight Kinudatami (silk mats) on the waves and sat on them to drown herself in the sea.

sen.j: すると波が穏やかになり、船を進めることが可能になった。
sen.e: Then the waves had subsided, making it possible for the ship to sail.
Then the waves had subsided, making it possible for the ship to sail.
Then the waves had subsided, making it possible for the ship to sail.

sen.j: 彼女が持っていた櫛は、七日後、海岸に流れ着いた。
sen.e: Her comb drifted to the seashore seven days later.
Her comb drifted to the seashore seven days later.
Her comb drifted to the seashore seven days later.

sen.j: 現在の東京湾沿岸には、こゆるぎという地名や、袖ヶ浦、袖ヶ浜などという地名が多くある。
sen.e: Near the Tokyo Bay area today, there are various place-names, such as Koyurugi, Sodegaura, and Sodegahama.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Near the Tokyo Bay area today, there are various place-names, such as Koyurugi, Sodegaura, and Sodegahama.
Near the Tokyo Bay area today, there are various place-names, such as Koyurugi, Sodegaura, and Sodegahama.

sen.j: これは弟橘媛の帯や袖が流れ着いたという伝説に基づいて名付けられた地名である。
sen.e: They are named after the legend which says that a part of Oto Tachibana Hime's kimono outfits, such as obi (sash) and sode (sleeve), drifted to the shores.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: They are named after the legend which says that a part of Oto Tachibana Hime's kimono outfits, such as obi (sash) and sode (sleeve), drifted to the shores.
They are named after the legend which says that a part of Oto Tachibana Hime's kimono outfits, such as obi (sash) and sode (sleeve), drifted to the shores.

sen.j: 媛を忘れられない尊は、『日本書紀』によれば碓日嶺（うすひのみね。現在の碓氷峠）、『古事記』によれば神奈川県の足柄の坂本（足柄山）において、「吾妻はや」（我が妻よ）と嘆いた。
sen.e: Yamatotakeru couldn't forget Oto Tachibana Hime and grieved, saying, "Ah, my wife," at Usuhinomine (present day Usui-toge Pass) according to "Nihonshoki" and at Sakamoto, Ashigara (Mr. Ashigara) in Kanagawa Prefecture according to "Kojiki."

Yamatotakeru could not forget Oto Tachibana Hime and grieved, saying, 'Ah, my wife,' at Usuhinomine (present day Usui-toge Pass) according to the "Nihonshoki" and at Sakamoto, Ashigara (Mt. Ashigara) in Kanagawa Prefecture according to the "Kojiki."
sen.cmt: couldn't→could notとし、Mr. Ashigara→Mt. Ashigaraに修正、一部シングルクォーテーションに変更、the "Nihonshoki"、the "Kojiki"としました。
sen.e: Yamatotakeru could not forget Oto Tachibana Hime and grieved, saying, 'Ah, my wife,' at Usuhinomine (present day Usui-toge Pass) according to the "Nihonshoki" and at Sakamoto, Ashigara (Mt. Ashigara) in Kanagawa Prefecture according to the "Kojiki."

sen.j: 日本の東部を「あずま」と呼ぶのは、この故事にちなむという。
sen.e: We call the eastern part of Japan, "Azuma," named after this legendary account.
We call the eastern part of Japan, 'Azuma,' named after this legendary account.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: We call the eastern part of Japan, 'Azuma,' named after this legendary account.

sen.j: いわゆる地名起源説話である。
sen.e: This is so-called narrative about the origin of the place-name.
This is so-called narrative about the origin of the place-name.
This is so-called narrative about the origin of the place-name.

sen.j: 『古事記』では弟橘姫は海に身を投じる際、下記のように詠んだ。
sen.e: In "Kojiki," before Oto Tachibana Hime drowned herself in the sea, she composed the following poem:
In the "Kojiki," before Oto Tachibana Hime drowned herself in the sea, she composed the following poem:
In the "Kojiki," before Oto Tachibana Hime drowned herself in the sea, she composed the following poem:

sen.j: さねさし 相武（さがむ）の小野に 燃ゆる火の 火中（ほなか）に立ちて 問ひし君はも
sen.e: You who inquired after my safety when we stood amidst of the burning field of Ono, Sagamu, with mountains rising high above.
sen.cmt: 日本語の現代語訳にする際に枕詞は訳さないとする場合もあるようですが、原文に忠実にするため、枕詞も訳に入れました。「さねさし」は内藤弘作著『枕詞便覧』によると、「「さ」は美称の接頭語。「ね」は「峯」で、「さし」は勢いよく立つことで、山が高く側だっている意だという (p.204)」枕詞であることから、左のような訳をつけました。同著によると「はも」は強い詠嘆を表します。
sen.e: You who inquired after my safety when we stood amidst of the burning field of Ono, Sagamu, with mountains rising high above.
You who inquired after my safety when we stood amidst of the burning field of Ono, Sagamu, with mountains rising high above.

sen.j: 佐泥佐斯 佐賀牟能袁怒邇 毛由流肥能 本那迦邇多知弖 斗比斯岐美波母
sen.e: You who inquired after my safety when we stood amidst of the burning field of Ono, Sagamu, with mountains rising high above.
sen.cmt: 29行目の詞の原文であるため、同じ訳を入れてあります。
sen.e: You who inquired after my safety when we stood amidst of the burning field of Ono, Sagamu, with mountains rising high above.
You who inquired after my safety when we stood amidst of the burning field of Ono, Sagamu, with mountains rising high above.

sen.j: 「相模の野に燃え立つ火の中で、わたしの心配をしてくださった貴方」という意味である。
sen.e: This poem means: "You who were worried about me when we were surrounded by the flaming fire in the fields of Sagami.
This poem means: 'You who were worried about me when we were surrounded by the flaming fire in the fields of Sagami.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーション不足分追加、シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: This poem means: 'You who were worried about me when we were surrounded by the flaming fire in the fields of Sagami.'

sen.j: 相模国の国造にだまされ、火攻めにあった時のことを言っている。
sen.e: This implies the incident in which Yamatotakeru was deceived and set fire by the Kuninomiyatsuko (provincial governor) who was in charge of Sagami Province.
This implies the incident in which Yamatotakeru was deceived and set fire by the Kuni no miyatsuko (provincial governor) who was in charge of Sagami Province.
This implies the incident in which Yamatotakeru was deceived and set fire by the Kuni no miyatsuko (provincial governor) who was in charge of Sagami Province.

sen.j: 古事記にのみ存在する歌である。
sen.e: This poem is only recorded in Kojiki.
This poem is only recorded in the Kojiki.
This poem is only recorded in the Kojiki.

sen.j: 尊に対する感謝の気持ちがよく表れている。
sen.e: Her gratitude to Yamatotakeru is well expressed in this poem.
Her gratitude to Yamatotakeru is well expressed in this poem.
Her gratitude to Yamatotakeru is well expressed in this poem.

sen.j: 尊の「吾妻はや」という言葉とあわせると、ふたりは固い絆で結ばれていたことがわかる。
sen.e: Considering together with Yamatotakeru's word, "Ah, my wife," we can know how strong the bond between them was.
Considering together with Yamatotakeru's word, 'Ah, my wife,' we can know how strong the bond between them was.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: Considering together with Yamatotakeru's word, 'Ah, my wife,' we can know how strong the bond between them was.

sen.j: 風土記の弟橘媛
sen.e: Oto Tachibana Hime recorded in the "Fudoki"
Oto Tachibana Hime recorded in the Fudoki
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Oto Tachibana Hime recorded in the Fudoki

sen.j: 常陸国風土記にも弟橘媛の姿は現れる。
sen.e: Oto Tachibana Hime also appears in "Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki."
Oto Tachibana Hime also appears in the Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除、the追加
sen.e: Oto Tachibana Hime also appears in the Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki.

sen.j: 同書において彼女は橘皇后（たちばなのおおきさき）、夫の日本武尊は倭武天皇（やまとたけるのすめらみこと）と表記されている。
sen.e: In the records, she is called as Tachibanano Okisaki and her husband, Yamatotakeru no Mikoto, is recorded as Yamatotakeru no Sumeramikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the records, she is referred to as Tachibana no Okisaki and her husband, Yamatotakeru no Mikoto, is recorded as Yamatotakeru no Sumeramikoto.
sen.cmt: she is called as→she is referred to as、Tachibanano Okisaki→Tachibana no Okisakiとしました。
sen.e: In the records, she is referred to as Tachibana no Okisaki and her husband, Yamatotakeru no Mikoto, is recorded as Yamatotakeru no Sumeramikoto.

sen.j: 尊は、大和国から降ってきた媛と常陸国の相鹿（あうか、現在の茨城県潮来市および同県行方市）で再会する。
sen.e: At Auka in Hitachi Province (present day Itako City and Namegata City in Ibaraki Prefecture), Yamatotakeru met again with Oto Tachibana Hime who came from Yamato Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At Auka in Hitachi Province (present day Itako City and Namegata City in Ibaraki Prefecture), Yamatotakeru met again with Oto Tachibana Hime who came from Yamato Province.
At Auka in Hitachi Province (present day Itako City and Namegata City in Ibaraki Prefecture), Yamatotakeru met again with Oto Tachibana Hime who came from Yamato Province.
